text: Now these are the names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob; they came, each one with his household:
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah;
speaker: Narrator

text: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people who descended from Jacob were seventy people, but Joseph was already in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joseph died, and all his brothers and all that generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the sons of Israel were fruitful and increased greatly, and multiplied, and became exceedingly mighty, so that the land was filled with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a new king arose over Egypt, who did not know Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to his people, “Behold, the people of the sons of Israel are too many and too mighty for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us deal shrewdly with them, otherwise they will multiply, and in the event of war, they will also join those who hate us, and fight against us and depart from the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they appointed taskmasters over them to oppress them with hard labor. And they built for Pharaoh storage cities, Pithom and Raamses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the more they oppressed them, the more they multiplied and the more they spread out, so that they dreaded the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians used violence to compel the sons of Israel to labor;
speaker: Narrator

text: and they made their lives bitter with hard labor in mortar and bricks and at all kinds of labor in the field, all their labors which they violently had them perform as slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was named Shiphrah, and the other was named Puah;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said, “When you are helping the Hebrew women to give birth and see them upon the birthstool, if it is a son, then you shall put him to death; but if it is a daughter, then she shall live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the midwives feared God, and did not do as the king of Egypt had commanded them, but let the boys live.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Egypt called for the midwives and said to them, “Why have you done this thing, and let the boys live?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The midwives said to Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women; for they are vigorous and give birth before the midwife can get to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God was good to the midwives, and the people multiplied, and became very mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because the midwives feared God, He established households for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh commanded all his people, saying, “Every son who is born, you are to throw into the Nile, but every daughter, you are to keep alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a man from the house of Levi went and married a daughter of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the woman conceived and gave birth to a son; and when she saw that he was beautiful, she hid him for three months.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when she could no longer hide him, she got him a papyrus basket and covered it with tar and pitch. Then she put the child in it and set it among the reeds by the bank of the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his sister stood at a distance to find out what would happen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the daughter of Pharaoh came down to bathe at the Nile, with her female attendants walking alongside the Nile; and she saw the basket among the reeds and sent her slave woman, and she brought it to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she opened it, she saw the child, and behold, the boy was crying. And she had pity on him and said, “This is one of the Hebrews’ children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, “Shall I go and call a woman for you who is nursing from the Hebrew women, so that she may nurse the child for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Go ahead.” So the girl went and called the child’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this child away and nurse him for me, and I will give you your wages.” So the woman took the child and nursed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the child grew, and she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter and he became her son. And she named him Moses, and said, “Because I drew him out of the water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it came about in those days, when Moses had grown up, that he went out to his fellow Hebrews and looked at their hard labors; and he saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his fellow Hebrews.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he looked this way and that, and when he saw that there was no one around, he struck and killed the Egyptian, and hid his body in the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now he went out the next day, and behold, two Hebrews were fighting with each other; and he said to the offender, “Why are you striking your companion?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Who made you a ruler and a judge over us? Do you intend to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?” Then Moses was afraid and said, “Surely the matter has become known!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh heard about this matter, he tried to kill Moses. But Moses fled from the presence of Pharaoh and settled in the land of Midian, and he sat down by a well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters; and they came to draw water and filled the troughs to water their father’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the shepherds came and drove them away, but Moses stood up and helped them and watered their flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to their father Reuel, he said, “Why have you come back so soon today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “An Egyptian saved us from the shepherds, and what is more, he even drew water for us and watered the flock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to his daughters, “Where is he then? Why is it that you have left the man behind? Invite him to have something to eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses was willing to live with the man. And he gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she gave birth to a son, and he named him Gershom, for he said, “I have been a stranger in a foreign land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it came about in the course of those many days that the king of Egypt died. And the sons of Israel groaned because of the bondage, and they cried out; and their cry for help because of their bondage ascended to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God heard their groaning; and God remembered His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God saw the sons of Israel, and God took notice of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses was pasturing the flock of his father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian; and he led the flock to the west side of the wilderness and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord appeared to him in a blazing fire from the midst of a bush; and he looked, and behold, the bush was burning with fire, yet the bush was not being consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said, “I must turn aside and see this marvelous sight, why the bush is not burning up!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that he turned aside to look, God called to him from the midst of the bush and said, “Moses, Moses!” And he said, “Here I am.”
speaker: God

text: Then He said, “Do not come near here; remove your sandals from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground.”
speaker: God

text: And He said, “I am the God of your father—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” Then Moses hid his face, for he was afraid to look at God.
speaker: God

text: And the Lord said, “I have certainly seen the oppression of My people who are in Egypt, and have heard their outcry because of their taskmasters, for I am aware of their sufferings.
speaker: God

text: So I have come down to rescue them from the power of the Egyptians, and to bring them up from that land to a good and spacious land, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite.
speaker: God

text: And now, behold, the cry of the sons of Israel has come to Me; furthermore, I have seen the oppression with which the Egyptians are oppressing them.
speaker: God

text: And now come, and I will send you to Pharaoh, so that you may bring My people, the sons of Israel, out of Egypt.”
speaker: God

text: But Moses said to God, “Who am I, that I should go to Pharaoh, and that I should bring the sons of Israel out of Egypt?”
speaker: God

text: And He said, “Assuredly I will be with you, and this shall be the sign to you that it is I who have sent you: when you have brought the people out of Egypt, you shall worship God at this mountain.”
speaker: God

text: Then Moses said to God, “Behold, I am going to the sons of Israel, and I will say to them, ‘The God of your fathers has sent me to you.’ Now they may say to me, ‘What is His name?’ What shall I say to them?”
speaker: God

text: And God said to Moses, “I AM WHO I AM”; and He said, “This is what you shall say to the sons of Israel: ‘I AM has sent me to you.’”
speaker: God

text: God furthermore said to Moses, “This is what you shall say to the sons of Israel: ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you.’ This is My name forever, and this is the name for all generations to use to call upon Me.
speaker: God

text: Go and gather the elders of Israel together and say to them, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob has appeared to me, saying, “I am indeed concerned about you and what has been done to you in Egypt.
speaker: God

text: So I said, I will bring you up out of the oppression of Egypt to the land of the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Amorite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite, to a land flowing with milk and honey.”’
speaker: God

text: Then they will pay attention to what you say; and you with the elders of Israel will come to the king of Egypt, and you will say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. So now, please let us go a three days’ journey into the wilderness, so that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God.’
speaker: God

text: But I know that the king of Egypt will not permit you to go, except under compulsion.
speaker: God

text: So I will reach out with My hand and strike Egypt with all My miracles which I shall do in the midst of it; and after that he will let you go.
speaker: God

text: I will grant this people favor in the sight of the Egyptians; and it shall be that when you go, you will not go empty-handed.
speaker: God

text: But every woman shall ask her neighbor and the woman who lives in her house for articles of silver and articles of gold, and clothing; and you will put them on your sons and daughters. So you will plunder the Egyptians.”
speaker: God

text: Then Moses said, “What if they will not believe me or listen to what I say? For they may say, ‘The Lord has not appeared to you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?” And he said, “A staff.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He said, “Throw it on the ground.” So he threw it on the ground, and it turned into a serpent; and Moses fled from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses, “Reach out with your hand and grasp it by its tail”—so he reached out with his hand and caught it, and it turned into a staff in his hand—
speaker: Narrator

text: “so that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord furthermore said to him, “Now put your hand inside the fold of your robe.” So he put his hand inside the fold, and when he took it out, behold, his hand was leprous like snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He said, “Put your hand inside the fold of your robe again.” So he put his hand into the fold again, and when he took it out of the fold, behold, it was restored like the rest of his flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So if they will not believe you nor pay attention to the evidence of the first sign, they may believe the evidence of the last sign.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they will not believe even these two signs nor pay attention to what you say, then you shall take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground; and the water which you take from the Nile will turn into blood on the dry ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the Lord, “Please, Lord, I have never been eloquent, neither recently nor in time past, nor since You have spoken to Your servant; for I am slow of speech and slow of tongue.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to him, “Who has made the human mouth? Or who makes anyone unable to speak or deaf, or able to see or blind? Is it not I, the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then go, and I Myself will be with your mouth, and instruct you in what you are to say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Please, Lord, now send the message by whomever You will.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anger of the Lord burned against Moses, and He said, “Is there not your brother Aaron the Levite? I know that he speaks fluently. And moreover, behold, he is coming out to meet you; when he sees you, he will be overjoyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you are to speak to him and put the words in his mouth; and I Myself will be with your mouth and his mouth, and I will instruct you in what you are to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall speak for you to the people; and he will be as a mouth for you and you will be as God to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall take in your hand this staff, with which you shall perform the signs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses departed and returned to his father-in-law Jethro, and said to him, “Please, let me go, that I may return to my brothers who are in Egypt, and see if they are still alive.” And Jethro said to Moses, “Go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt, for all the men who were seeking your life are dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took his wife and his sons and mounted them on a donkey, and returned to the land of Egypt. Moses also took the staff of God in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses, “When you go back to Egypt, see that you perform before Pharaoh all the wonders which I have put in your power; but I will harden his heart so that he will not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you shall say to Pharaoh, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Israel is My son, My firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said to you, ‘Let My son go so that he may serve Me’; but you have refused to let him go. Behold, I am going to kill your son, your firstborn.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But it came about at the overnight encampment on the way, that the Lord met Moses, and sought to put him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zipporah took a flint and cut off her son’s foreskin and threw it at Moses’ feet; and she said, “You are indeed a groom of blood to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So He left him alone. At that time she said, “You are a groom of blood”—because of the circumcision.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Aaron, “Go to meet Moses in the wilderness.” So he went and met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord with which He had sent him, and all the signs that He had commanded him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went and assembled all the elders of the sons of Israel;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Aaron spoke all the words which the Lord had spoken to Moses. He then performed the signs in the sight of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people believed; and when they heard that the Lord was concerned about the sons of Israel and that He had seen their affliction, they bowed low and worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text: And afterward Moses and Aaron came and said to Pharaoh, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel says: ‘Let My people go so that they may celebrate a feast to Me in the wilderness.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord that I should obey His voice to let Israel go? I do not know the Lord, and besides, I will not let Israel go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please, let us go a three days’ journey into the wilderness so that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God, otherwise He will strike us with plague or with the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why do you let the people neglect their work? Get back to your labors!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again Pharaoh said, “Look, the people of the land are now many, and you would have them cease from their labors!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the same day Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters over the people and their foremen, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are no longer to give the people straw to make bricks as previously; have them go and gather straw for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you shall impose on them the quota of bricks which they were making before; you are not to reduce any of it. Because they are lazy, for that reason they cry out, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to our God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the labor be heavier on the men, and have them work at it so that they will pay no attention to false words.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the taskmasters of the people and their foremen went out and spoke to the people, saying, “This is what Pharaoh says: ‘I am not going to give you any straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: You go, get straw for yourselves wherever you can find it; but none of your labor will be reduced.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people scattered through all the land of Egypt to gather stubble for straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the taskmasters pressed them, saying, “Complete your work quota, your daily amount, just as when you had straw.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the foremen of the sons of Israel, whom Pharaoh’s taskmasters had set over them, were beaten and asked, “Why have you not completed your required task of making bricks either yesterday or today, as before?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the foremen of the sons of Israel came and cried out to Pharaoh, saying, “Why do you deal this way with your servants?
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no straw given to your servants, yet they keep saying to us, ‘Make bricks!’ And behold, your servants are being beaten; but it is the fault of your own people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “You are lazy, very lazy; for that reason you say, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So go now and work; for you will be given no straw, but you must deliver the quota of bricks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The foremen of the sons of Israel saw that they were in trouble, since they were told, “You must not reduce your daily amount of bricks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they left Pharaoh’s presence, they met Moses and Aaron as they were waiting for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to them, “May the Lord look upon you and judge you, because you have made us repulsive in Pharaoh’s sight and in the sight of his servants, to put a sword in their hand to kill us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses returned to the Lord and said, “Lord, why have You brought harm to this people? Why did You ever send me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Ever since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has done harm to this people, and You have not rescued Your people at all.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Now you shall see what I will do to Pharaoh; for under compulsion he will let them go, and under compulsion he will drive them out of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God spoke further to Moses and said to him, “I am the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text: and I appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but by My name, Lord, I did not make Myself known to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also established My covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land in which they lived as strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore I have heard the groaning of the sons of Israel, because the Egyptians are holding them in bondage, and I have remembered My covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say, therefore, to the sons of Israel, ‘I am the Lord, and I will bring you out from under the labors of the Egyptians, and I will rescue you from their bondage. I will also redeem you with an outstretched arm, and with great judgments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will take you as My people, and I will be your God; and you shall know that I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from under the labors of the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you to the land which I swore to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and I will give it to you as a possession; I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said this to the sons of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses on account of their despondency and cruel bondage.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the sons of Israel go out of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses spoke before the Lord, saying, “Behold, the sons of Israel have not listened to me; how then will Pharaoh listen to me, as I am unskilled in speech?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron and gave them a command concerning the sons of Israel and Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring the sons of Israel out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the heads of their fathers’ households. The sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn: Hanoch and Pallu, Hezron and Carmi; these are the families of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman; these are the families of Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And these are the names of the sons of Levi according to their generations: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari; and the length of Levi’s life was 137 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gershon: Libni and Shimei, according to their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel; and the length of Kohath’s life was 133 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites according to their generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Amram married his father’s sister Jochebed, and she bore him Aaron and Moses; and the length of Amram’s life was 137 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Izhar: Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Uzziel: Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron married Elisheba, the daughter of Amminadab, the sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Korah: Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph; these are the families of the Korahites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Aaron’s son Eleazar married one of the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas. These are the heads of the fathers’ households of the Levites according to their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the same Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring out the sons of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their multitudes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were the ones who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt about bringing out the sons of Israel from Egypt; it was the same Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it came about on the day when the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: that the Lord spoke to Moses, saying, “I am the Lord; say to Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I say to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said before the Lord, “Behold, I am unskilled in speech; how then will Pharaoh listen to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “See, I have made you as God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron shall be your prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, you shall speak all that I command you, and your brother Aaron shall speak to Pharaoh that he let the sons of Israel go out of his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, so that I may multiply My signs and My wonders in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh does not listen to you, I will lay My hand on Egypt and bring out My armies, My people the sons of Israel, from the land of Egypt by great judgments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord, when I extend My hand over Egypt and bring out the sons of Israel from their midst.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron did this; as the Lord commanded them, so they did.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three, when they spoke to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Pharaoh speaks to you, saying, ‘Work a miracle,’ then you shall say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh, so that it may turn into a serpent.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron came to Pharaoh, and so they did, just as the Lord had commanded; and Aaron threw his staff down before Pharaoh and his servants, and it turned into a serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh also called for the wise men and the sorcerers, and they too, the soothsayer priests of Egypt, did the same with their secret arts.
speaker: Narrator

text: For each one threw down his staff, and they turned into serpents. But Aaron’s staff swallowed their staffs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is stubborn; he refuses to let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning just as he is going out to the water, and position yourself to meet him on the bank of the Nile; and you shall take in your hand the staff that was turned into a serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, sent me to you, saying, “Let My people go, so that they may serve Me in the wilderness. But behold, you have not listened up to now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: “By this you shall know that I am the Lord: behold, I am going to strike the water that is in the Nile with the staff that is in my hand, and it will be turned into blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the fish that are in the Nile will die, the Nile will stink, and the Egyptians will no longer be able to drink water from the Nile.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and extend your hand over the waters of Egypt, over their rivers, over their streams, over their pools, and over all their reservoirs of water, so that they may become blood; and there will be blood through all the land of Egypt, both in containers of wood and in containers of stone.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord had commanded. And he lifted up the staff and struck the water that was in the Nile in the sight of Pharaoh and in the sight of his servants; and all the water that was in the Nile was turned into blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the fish that were in the Nile died, and the Nile stank, so that the Egyptians could not drink water from the Nile. And the blood was through all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the soothsayer priests of Egypt did the same with their secret arts; and Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh turned and went into his house with no concern even for this.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the Egyptians dug around the Nile for water to drink, because they could not drink from the water of the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days passed after the Lord had struck the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Let My people go, so that they may serve Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you refuse to let them go, behold, I am going to strike your entire territory with frogs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nile will swarm with frogs, which will come up and go into your house, and into your bedroom and on your bed, and into the houses of your servants, and on your people, and into your ovens and kneading bowls.

text: So the frogs will come up on you, your people, and on all your servants.”’”

text: So Aaron extended his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.

text: Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron and said, “Plead with the Lord to remove the frogs from me and from my people; and I will let the people go, so that they may sacrifice to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said to Pharaoh, “The honor is yours to tell me: when shall I plead for you and your servants and your people, that the frogs be destroyed from you and your houses, that they be left only in the Nile?”

text: Then he said, “Tomorrow.” So he said, “May it be according to your word, so that you may know that there is no one like the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The frogs will depart from you and your houses, and from your servants and your people; they will be left only in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the Lord concerning the frogs which He had inflicted upon Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did according to the word of Moses, and the frogs died out of the houses, the courtyards, and the fields.

text: So they piled them in heaps, and the land stank.

text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.

speaker: Narrator

text: The soothsayer priests tried with their secret arts to produce gnats, but they could not; so there were gnats on every person and animal.

text: Then the soothsayer priests said to Pharaoh, “This is the finger of God.” But Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Rise early in the morning and present yourself before Pharaoh, as he comes out to the water; and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Let My people go, so that they may serve Me.

text: For if you are not going to let My people go, behold, I will send swarms of flies on you and on your servants and on your people, and into your houses; and the houses of the Egyptians will be full of swarms of flies, and also the ground on which they live.

text: But Moses said, “It is not permissible for us to do so, because we will sacrifice to the Lord our God that which is an abomination to the Egyptians. If we sacrifice that which is an abomination to the Egyptians before their eyes, will they not stone us?

text: We must go a three days’ journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the Lord our God, just as He commands us.”
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “Behold, I am going to leave you, and I will plead with the Lord that the swarms of flies may depart from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people tomorrow; only do not let Pharaoh deal deceitfully again in not letting the people go to sacrifice to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses left Pharaoh and pleaded with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did as Moses asked, and removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people; not one remained.

speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and speak to him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews says: “Let My people go, so that they may serve Me.

text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had spoken to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Rise up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews says: “Let My people go, so that they may serve Me.

text: For this time I am going to send all My plagues on you and your servants and your people, so that you may know that there is no one like Me in all the earth.

speaker: Narrator

text: but everyone who did not pay regard to the word of the Lord left his servants and his livestock in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Moses, “Reach out with your hand toward the sky, so that hail may fall on all the land of Egypt, on every person and animal, and on every plant of the field, throughout the land of Egypt.”

text: Only in the land of Goshen, where the sons of Israel were, was there no hail.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not let the sons of Israel go, just as the Lord had spoken through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said to him, “This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews says: ‘How long will you refuse to humble yourself before Me? Let My people go, so that they may serve Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh’s servants said to him, “How long shall this man be a snare to us? Let the people go, so that they may serve the Lord their God. Do you not yet realize that Egypt is destroyed?”

speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh hurriedly called for Moses and Aaron, and he said, “I have sinned against the Lord your God and against you.

text: Then he left Pharaoh and pleaded with the Lord.

speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This month shall be the beginning of months for you; it is to be the first month of the year for you.

text: Now if the household is too small for a lamb, then he and his neighbor nearest to his house are to take one according to the number of persons in them; in proportion to what each one should eat, you are to divide the lamb.

text: Your lamb shall be an unblemished male a year old; you may take it from the sheep or from the goats.

text: You shall keep it until the fourteenth day of the same month, then the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel is to slaughter it at twilight.

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall not leave any of it over until morning, but whatever is left of it until morning, you shall completely burn with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you shall eat it in this way: with your garment belted around your waist, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand; and you shall eat it in a hurry—it is the Lord’s Passover.

text: For I will go through the land of Egypt on that night, and fatally strike all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the human firstborn to animals; and against all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgments—I am the Lord.

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days there shall be no dough with yeast found in your houses; for whoever eats anything with yeast, that person shall be cut off from the congregation of Israel, whether he is a stranger or a native of the land.

text: You shall not eat anything with yeast; in all your dwellings you shall eat unleavened bread.’”

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: So it shall serve as a sign on your hand and as phylacteries on your forehead, for with a powerful hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Pharaoh had let the people go, God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, even though it was near; for God said, “The people might change their minds when they see war, and return to Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore God led the people around by way of the wilderness to the Red Sea; and the sons of Israel went up in battle formation from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for he had made the sons of Israel solemnly swear, saying, “God will certainly take care of you, and you shall carry my bones from here with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they set out from Succoth and camped in Etham, on the edge of the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord was going before them in a pillar of cloud by day to lead them on the way, and in a pillar of fire by night to give them light, so that they might travel by day and by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not take away the pillar of cloud by day, nor the pillar of fire by night, from the presence of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the sons of Israel to turn back and camp in front of Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea; you shall camp in front of Baal-zephon, opposite it, by the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Pharaoh will say of the sons of Israel, ‘They are wandering aimlessly in the land; the wilderness has shut them in.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and he will chase after them; and I will be honored through Pharaoh and all his army, and the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.” And they did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, Pharaoh and his servants had a change of heart toward the people, and they said, “What is this that we have done, that we have let Israel go from serving us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he had horses harnessed to his chariot and took his people with him;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he took six hundred select chariots, and all the other chariots of Egypt with officers over all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and he chased after the sons of Israel as the sons of Israel were going out boldly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Egyptians chased after them with all the horses and chariots of Pharaoh, his horsemen and his army, and they overtook them camping by the sea, beside Pi-hahiroth, in front of Baal-zephon.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Pharaoh approached, the sons of Israel looked, and behold, the Egyptians were coming after them, and they became very frightened; so the sons of Israel cried out to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to Moses, “Is it because there were no graves in Egypt that you have taken us away to die in the wilderness? Why have you dealt with us in this way, bringing us out of Egypt?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this not the word that we spoke to you in Egypt, saying, ‘Leave us alone so that we may serve the Egyptians’? For it would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the wilderness!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the people, “Do not fear! Stand by and see the salvation of the Lord, which He will perform for you today; for the Egyptians whom you have seen today, you will never see them again, ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will fight for you, while you keep silent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Why are you crying out to Me? Tell the sons of Israel to go forward.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, lift up your staff and reach out with your hand over the sea and divide it, and the sons of Israel shall go through the midst of the sea on dry land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for Me, behold, I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will go in after them; and I will be honored through Pharaoh and all his army, through his chariots and his horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord, when I am honored through Pharaoh, through his chariots, and through his horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of God, who had been going before the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them; and the pillar of cloud moved from before them and stood behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it came between the camp of Egypt and the camp of Israel; and there was the cloud along with the darkness, yet it gave light at night. Therefore the one did not approach the other all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses reached out with his hand over the sea; and the Lord swept the sea back by a strong east wind all night, and turned the sea into dry land, and the waters were divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the sons of Israel went through the midst of the sea on the dry land, and the waters were like a wall to them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Egyptians took up the pursuit, and all Pharaoh’s horses, his chariots, and his horsemen went in after them into the midst of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: But at the morning watch, the Lord looked down on the army of the Egyptians through the pillar of fire and cloud, and brought the army of the Egyptians into confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: He caused their chariot wheels to swerve, and He made them drive with difficulty; so the Egyptians each said, “Let me flee from Israel, for the Lord is fighting for them against the Egyptians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Reach out with your hand over the sea so that the waters may come back over the Egyptians, over their chariots and their horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses reached out with his hand over the sea, and the sea returned to its normal state at daybreak, while the Egyptians were fleeing right into it; then the Lord overthrew the Egyptians in the midst of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters returned and covered the chariots and the horsemen, Pharaoh’s entire army that had gone into the sea after them; not even one of them remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the sons of Israel walked on dry land through the midst of the sea, and the waters were like a wall to them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord saved Israel that day from the hand of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel saw the great power which the Lord had used against the Egyptians, the people feared the Lord, and they believed in the Lord and in His servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The Lord is a warrior;
The Lord is His name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pharaoh’s chariots and his army He has thrown into the sea;
And the choicest of his officers are drowned in the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters cover them;
They went down into the depths like a stone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your right hand, Lord, is majestic in power;
Your right hand, Lord, destroys the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And in the greatness of Your excellence You overthrow those who rise up against You;
You send out Your burning anger, and it consumes them like chaff.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
You blew with Your wind, the sea covered them;
They sank like lead in the mighty waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is like You among the gods, Lord?
Who is like You, majestic in holiness,
Awesome in praises, working wonders?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You reached out with Your right hand,
The earth swallowed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In Your faithfulness You have led the people whom You have redeemed;
In Your strength You have guided them to Your holy habitation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The peoples have heard, they tremble;
Anguish has gripped the inhabitants of Philistia.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

Terror and dread fall upon them;
By the greatness of Your arm they are motionless as stone,
Until Your people pass over, Lord,
Until the people pass over whom You have purchased.

You will bring them and plant them in the mountain of Your inheritance,
The place, Lord, which You have made as Your dwelling,
The sanctuary, Lord, which Your hands have established.

text: The Lord shall reign forever and ever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the horses of Pharaoh with his chariots and his horsemen went into the sea, and the Lord brought back the waters of the sea on them, but the sons of Israel walked on dry land through the midst of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Miriam the prophetess, Aaron’s sister, took the tambourine in her hand, and all the women went out after her with tambourines and with dancing.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Moses led Israel from the Red Sea, and they went out into the wilderness of Shur; and they went three days in the wilderness and found no water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Marah, they could not drink the waters of Marah, because they were bitter; for that reason it was named Marah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people grumbled at Moses, saying, “What are we to drink?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he cried out to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a tree; and he threw it into the waters, and the waters became sweet.
There He made for them a statute and regulation, and there He tested them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He said, “If you will listen carefully to the voice of the Lord your God, and do what is right in His sight, and listen to His commandments, and keep all His statutes, I will put none of the diseases on you which I have put on the Egyptians; for I, the Lord, am your healer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to Elim where there were twelve springs of water and seventy date palms, and they camped there beside the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they set out from Elim, and all the congregation of the sons of Israel came to the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after their departure from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the whole congregation of the sons of Israel grumbled against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Israel said to them, “If only we had died by the Lord’s hand in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the pots of meat, when we ate bread until we were full; for you have brought us out into this wilderness to kill this entire assembly with hunger!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Behold, I will rain bread from heaven for you; and the people shall go out and gather a day’s portion every day, so that I may test them, whether or not they will walk in My instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day, when they prepare what they bring in, it will be twice as much as they gather daily.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the sons of Israel, “At evening you will know that the Lord has brought you out of the land of Egypt;
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the morning you will see the glory of the Lord, for He hears your grumblings against the Lord; and what are we, that you grumble against us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said, “This will happen when the Lord gives you meat to eat in the evening, and bread to the full in the morning; for the Lord hears your grumblings which you grumble against Him. And what are we? Your grumblings are not against us but against the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Say to all the congregation of the sons of Israel, ‘Come forward before the Lord, for He has heard your grumblings.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came about, as Aaron spoke to the entire congregation of the sons of Israel, that they looked toward the wilderness, and behold, the glory of the Lord appeared in the cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have heard the grumblings of the sons of Israel; speak to them, saying, ‘At twilight you shall eat meat, and in the morning you shall be filled with bread; and you shall know that I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So it came about at evening that the quails came up and covered the camp, and in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the layer of dew evaporated, behold, on the surface of the wilderness there was a fine flake-like thing, fine as the frost on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sons of Israel saw it, they said to one another, “What is it?” For they did not know what it was. And Moses said to them, “It is the bread which the Lord has given you to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘Everyone gather as much as he will eat; you shall take an omer apiece according to the number of people each of you has in his tent.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Israel did so, and some gathered much and some little.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they measured it by the omer, the one who had gathered much did not have too much, and the one who had gathered little did not have too little; everyone gathered as much as he would eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to them, “No one is to leave any of it until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen to Moses, and some left part of it until morning, and it bred worms and stank; and Moses was angry with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gathered it morning by morning, everyone as much as he would eat; but when the sun became hot, it would melt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on the sixth day they gathered twice as much bread, two omers for each one. When all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: then he said to them, “This is what the Lord meant: Tomorrow is a Sabbath observance, a holy Sabbath to the Lord. Bake what you will bake and boil what you will boil, and all that is left over put aside to be kept until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they put it aside until morning, as Moses had ordered, and it did not stink nor was there a maggot in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “Eat it today, for today is a Sabbath to the Lord; today you will not find it in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you shall gather it, but on the seventh day, the Sabbath, there will be none.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet it came about on the seventh day that some of the people went out to gather, but they found none.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “How long do you refuse to keep My commandments and My instructions?
speaker: Narrator

text: See, the Lord has given you the Sabbath; for that reason He gives you bread for two days on the sixth day. Remain, everyone, in his place; no one is to leave his place on the seventh day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the house of Israel named the bread manna, and it was like coriander seed, white, and its taste was like wafers with honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘A full omer of it is to be kept safe throughout your generations, so that they may see the bread that I fed you in the wilderness, when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said to Aaron, “Take a jar and put a full omer of manna in it, and place it before the Lord to be kept safe throughout your generations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord commanded Moses, so Aaron placed it before the Testimony, to be kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Israel ate the manna for forty years, until they came to an inhabited land; they ate the manna until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now an omer is a tenth of an ephah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the congregation of the sons of Israel journeyed by stages from the wilderness of Sin, according to the command of the Lord, and camped at Rephidim, and there was no water for the people to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people quarreled with Moses and said, “Give us water so that we may drink!” And Moses said to them, “Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you test the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were thirsty for water there; and they grumbled against Moses and said, “Why is it that you have brought us up from Egypt, to kill us and our children and our livestock with thirst?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses cried out to the Lord, saying, “What am I to do with this people? A little more and they will stone me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pass before the people and take with you some of the elders of Israel; and take in your hand your staff with which you struck the Nile, and go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, I will stand before you there on the rock at Horeb; and you shall strike the rock, and water will come out of it, so that the people may drink.” And Moses did so in the sight of the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he named the place Massah and Meribah because of the quarrel of the sons of Israel, and because they tested the Lord, saying, “Is the Lord among us, or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amalek came and fought against Israel at Rephidim.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to Joshua, “Choose men for us and go out, fight against Amalek. Tomorrow I will station myself on the top of the hill with the staff of God in my hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua did just as Moses told him, and fought against Amalek; and Moses, Aaron, and Hur went up to the top of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it came about, when Moses held his hand up, that Israel prevailed; but when he let his hand down, Amalek prevailed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses’ hands were heavy. So they took a stone and put it under him, and he sat on it; and Aaron and Hur supported his hands, one on one side and one on the other. So his hands were steady until the sun set.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua defeated Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Write this in a book as a memorial and recite it to Joshua, that I will utterly wipe out the memory of Amalek from under heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses built an altar and named it The Lord is My Banner;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said, “Because the Lord has sworn, the Lord will have war against Amalek from generation to generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jethro, the priest of Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard about everything that God had done for Moses and for Israel His people, how the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, took in Moses’ wife Zipporah, after he had sent her away,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her two sons, one of whom was named Gershom, for Moses said, “I have been a stranger in a foreign land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the other was named Eliezer, for he said, “The God of my father was my help, and saved me from the sword of Pharaoh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, came with his sons and his wife to Moses in the wilderness where he was camped, at the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sent word to Moses: “I, your father-in-law Jethro, am coming to you with your wife and her two sons with her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went out to meet his father-in-law, and he bowed down and kissed him; and they asked each other about their welfare, and went into the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told his father-in-law everything that the Lord had done to Pharaoh and to the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, all the hardship that had confronted them on the journey, and how the Lord had rescued them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jethro rejoiced over all the goodness which the Lord had done for Israel, in rescuing them from the hand of the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jethro said, “Blessed be the Lord who rescued you from the hand of the Egyptians and from the hand of Pharaoh, and who rescued the people from under the hand of the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I know that the Lord is greater than all the gods; indeed, it was proven when they acted insolently against the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, took a burnt offering and sacrifices for God, and Aaron came with all the elders of Israel to eat a meal with Moses’ father-in-law before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came about the next day, that Moses sat to judge the people, and the people stood before Moses from the morning until the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Moses’ father-in-law saw all that he was doing for the people, he said, “What is this thing that you are doing for the people? Why do you alone sit as judge and all the people stand before you from morning until evening?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to his father-in-law, “Because the people come to me to inquire of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they have a dispute, it comes to me, and I judge between someone and his neighbor and make known the statutes of God and His laws.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law then said to him, “The thing that you are doing is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will surely wear out, both yourself and these people who are with you, because the task is too heavy for you; you cannot do it alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now listen to me: I will give you counsel, and God be with you. You be the people’s representative before God, and you bring the disputes to God,
speaker: Narrator

text: then admonish them about the statutes and the laws, and make known to them the way in which they are to walk and the work they are to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, you shall select out of all the people able men who fear God, men of truth, those who hate dishonest gain; and you shall place these over them as leaders of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties, and of tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them judge the people at all times; and let it be that they will bring to you every major matter, but they will judge every minor matter themselves. So it will be easier for you, and they will carry the burden with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do this thing and God so commands you, then you will be able to endure, and all these people also will go to their places in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses listened to his father-in-law and did everything that he had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses chose able men out of all Israel and made them heads over the people, leaders of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties, and of tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they judged the people at all times; they would bring the difficult matter to Moses, but they would judge every minor matter themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said goodbye to his father-in-law, and Jethro went his way to his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third month after the sons of Israel had gone out of the land of Egypt, on that very day they came into the wilderness of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they set out from Rephidim, they came to the wilderness of Sinai and camped in the wilderness; and there Israel camped in front of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses went up to God, and the Lord called to him from the mountain, saying, “This is what you shall say to the house of Jacob and tell the sons of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You yourselves have seen what I did to the Egyptians, and how I carried you on eagles’ wings, and brought you to Myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, if you will indeed obey My voice and keep My covenant, then you shall be My own possession among all the peoples, for all the earth is Mine;
speaker: Narrator

text: and you shall be to Me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.’ These are the words that you shall speak to the sons of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses came and called the elders of the people, and set before them all these words which the Lord had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people answered together and said, “All that the Lord has spoken we will do!” And Moses brought back the words of the people to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Behold, I will come to you in a thick cloud, so that the people may hear when I speak with you and may also trust in you forever.” Then Moses told the words of the people to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said to Moses, “Go to the people and consecrate them today and tomorrow, and have them wash their garments;
speaker: Narrator

text: and have them ready for the third day, for on the third day the Lord will come down on Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you shall set boundaries for the people all around, saying, ‘Beware that you do not go up on the mountain or touch the border of it; whoever touches the mountain shall certainly be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: No hand shall touch him, but he shall certainly be stoned or shot through; whether animal or person, the violator shall not live.’ When the ram’s horn sounds a long blast, they shall come up to the mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went down from the mountain to the people and consecrated the people, and they washed their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also said to the people, “Be ready for the third day; do not go near a woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So it came about on the third day, when it was morning, that there were thunder and lightning flashes and a thick cloud over the mountain and a very loud trumpet sound, so that all the people who were in the camp trembled.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses brought the people out of the camp to meet God, and they stood at the foot of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Mount Sinai was all in smoke because the Lord descended upon it in fire; and its smoke ascended like the smoke of a furnace, and the entire mountain quaked violently.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sound of the trumpet grew louder and louder, Moses spoke, and God answered him with thunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down on Mount Sinai, to the top of the mountain; and the Lord called Moses to the top of the mountain, and Moses went up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses: “Go down, warn the people, so that they do not break through to the Lord to stare, and many of them perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also have the priests who approach the Lord consecrate themselves, or else the Lord will break out against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said to the Lord, “The people cannot come up to Mount Sinai, for You warned us, saying, ‘Set boundaries around the mountain and consecrate it.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “Go down and come up again, you and Aaron with you; but do not let the priests and the people break through to come up to the Lord, or He will break out against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went down to the people and told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God spoke all these words, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall have no other gods before Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not make for yourself an idol, or any likeness of what is in heaven above or on the earth beneath, or in the water under the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not worship them nor serve them; for I, the Lord your God, am a jealous God, inflicting the punishment of the fathers on the children, on the third and the fourth generations of those who hate Me,
speaker: Narrator

text: but showing favor to thousands, to those who love Me and keep My commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain, for the Lord will not leave him unpunished who takes His name in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For six days you shall labor and do all your work,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the seventh day is a Sabbath of the Lord your God; on it you shall not do any work, you, or your son, or your daughter, your male slave or your female slave, or your cattle, or your resident who stays with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth, the sea and everything that is in them, and He rested on the seventh day; for that reason the Lord blessed the Sabbath day and made it holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Honor your father and your mother, so that your days may be prolonged on the land which the Lord your God gives you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not murder.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not give false testimony against your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not covet your neighbor’s house; you shall not covet your neighbor’s wife, or his male slave, or his female slave, or his ox, or his donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the people were watching and hearing the thunder and the lightning flashes, and the sound of the trumpet, and the mountain smoking; and when the people saw it all, they trembled and stood at a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to Moses, “Speak to us yourself and we will listen; but do not have God speak to us, or we will die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid; for God has come in order to test you, and in order that the fear of Him may remain with you, so that you will not sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people stood at a distance, while Moses approached the thick darkness where God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “This is what you shall say to the sons of Israel: ‘You yourselves have seen that I have spoken to you from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not make other gods besides Me; gods of silver or gods of gold, you shall not make for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make an altar of earth for Me, and you shall sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and your peace offerings, your sheep and your oxen; in every place where I cause My name to be remembered, I will come to you and bless you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you make an altar of stone for Me, you shall not build it of cut stones, for if you wield your chisel on it, you will profane it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall not go up by steps to My altar, so that your nakedness will not be exposed on it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now these are the ordinances which you are to set before them:
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you buy a Hebrew slave, he shall serve for six years; but on the seventh he shall leave as a free man without a payment to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he comes alone, he shall leave alone; if he is the husband of a wife, then his wife shall leave with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his master gives him a wife, and she bears him sons or daughters, the wife and her children shall belong to her master, and he shall leave alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the slave plainly says, ‘I love my master, my wife, and my children; I will not leave as a free man,’
speaker: Narrator

text: then his master shall bring him to God, then he shall bring him to the door or the doorpost. And his master shall pierce his ear with an awl; and he shall serve him permanently.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now if a man sells his daughter as a female slave, she is not to go free as the male slaves do.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she is displeasing in the eyes of her master who designated her for himself, then he shall let her be redeemed. He does not have authority to sell her to a foreign people, because of his unfairness to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if he designates her for his son, he shall deal with her according to the custom of daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he takes to himself another woman, he may not reduce her food, her clothing, or her conjugal rights.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he will not do these three things for her, then she shall go free for nothing, without payment of money.
speaker: Narrator

text: “He who strikes someone so that he dies shall certainly be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet if he did not lie in wait for him, but God caused him to fall into his hand, then I will appoint you a place to which he may flee.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, someone is enraged against his neighbor, so as to kill him in a cunning way, you are to take him even from My altar, to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And one who strikes his father or his mother shall certainly be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now one who kidnaps someone, whether he sells him or he is found in his possession, shall certainly be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And one who curses his father or his mother shall certainly be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now if people have a quarrel and one strikes the other with a stone or with a fist, and he does not die but is confined to bed,
speaker: Narrator

text: if he gets up and walks around outside on his staff, then he who struck him shall go unpunished; he shall only pay for his loss of time, and shall pay for his care until he is completely healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And if someone strikes his male or female slave with a rod and the slave dies at his hand, he shall be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the slave survives a day or two, no vengeance shall be taken; for the slave is his property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now if people struggle with each other and strike a pregnant woman so that she gives birth prematurely, but there is no injury, the guilty person shall certainly be fined as the woman’s husband may demand of him, and he shall pay as the judges decide.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if there is any further injury, then you shall appoint as a penalty life for life,
speaker: Narrator

text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: burn for burn, wound for wound, bruise for bruise.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And if someone strikes the eye of his male or female slave and destroys it, he shall let the slave go free on account of the eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if he knocks out a tooth of his male or female slave, he shall let the slave go free on account of the tooth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now if an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox shall certainly be stoned and its flesh shall not be eaten; but the owner of the ox shall go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, an ox was previously in the habit of goring and its owner has been warned, yet he does not confine it and it kills a man or a woman, the ox shall be stoned and its owner also shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a ransom is demanded of him, then he shall give for the redemption of his life whatever is demanded of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether it gores a son or a daughter, it shall be done to him according to the same rule.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the ox gores a male or female slave, the owner shall give his or her master thirty shekels of silver, and the ox shall be stoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now if someone opens a pit, or digs a pit and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
speaker: Narrator

text: the owner of the pit shall make restitution; he shall give money to its owner, and the dead animal shall become his.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And if someone’s ox injures another’s ox so that it dies, then they shall sell the live ox and divide its proceeds equally; and they shall also divide the dead ox.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or if it is known that the ox was previously in the habit of goring, yet its owner has not confined it, he must make restitution of ox for ox, and the dead animal shall become his.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone steals an ox or a sheep and slaughters it or sells it, he shall pay five oxen for the ox and four sheep for the sheep—
speaker: Narrator

text: If the thief is caught while breaking in and is struck so that he dies, there will be no guilt for bloodshed on his account.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the sun has risen on him, there will be guilt for bloodshed on his account—A thief shall certainly make restitution; if he owns nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft.
speaker: Narrator

text: If what he stole is actually found alive in his possession, whether an ox or a donkey or a sheep, he shall pay double.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone lets a field or vineyard be grazed bare and lets his animal loose so that it grazes in another person’s field, he shall make restitution from the best of his own field and the best of his own vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a fire breaks out and spreads to thorn bushes, and stacked grain or the standing grain or the field itself is consumed, the one who started the fire must make restitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone gives his neighbor money or goods to keep for him and it is stolen from the neighbor’s house, if the thief is caught, then the thief shall pay double.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the thief is not caught, then the owner of the house shall appear before the judges, to determine whether he laid his hands on his neighbor’s property.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every breach of trust, whether it is for ox, for donkey, for sheep, for clothing, or for any lost thing about which one says, ‘This is it,’ the case of both parties shall come before the judges; he whom the judges condemn shall pay double to his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone gives his neighbor a donkey, an ox, a sheep, or any animal to keep for him, and it dies or is injured or is driven away while no one is looking,
speaker: Narrator

text: an oath before the Lord shall be taken by the two of them that he has not laid a hand on his neighbor’s property; and its owner shall accept it, and he shall not be compelled to make restitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it is actually stolen from him, he shall make restitution to its owner.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is all torn to pieces, have him bring it as evidence; he shall not be compelled to make restitution for what has been torn to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And if someone borrows an animal from his neighbor, and it is injured or dies while its owner is not with it, he shall make full restitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: If its owner is with it, the borrower shall not be compelled to make restitution. If it is hired, it came by its hire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man seduces a virgin who is not betrothed and sleeps with her, he must pay a dowry for her to be his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: If her father absolutely refuses to give her to him, he shall pay money equal to the dowry for virgins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not allow a sorceress to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever has sexual intercourse with an animal must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “He who sacrifices to any god, other than to the Lord alone, shall be utterly destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not oppress a stranger nor torment him, for you were strangers in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not oppress any widow or orphan.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you oppress him at all, and if he does cry out to Me, I will assuredly hear his cry;
speaker: Narrator

text: and My anger will be kindled, and I will kill you with the sword, and your wives shall become widows and your children fatherless.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you lend money to My people, to the poor among you, you are not to act as a creditor to him; you shall not charge him interest.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you ever seize your neighbor’s cloak as a pledge, you are to return it to him before the sun sets,
speaker: Narrator

text: for that is his only covering; it is his cloak for his body. What else is he to sleep in? And it will come about that when he cries out to Me, I will listen to him, for I am gracious.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not curse God, nor curse a ruler of your people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not hold back the offering from your entire harvest and your wine. The firstborn of your sons you shall give to Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall do the same with your oxen and with your sheep. It shall be with its mother for seven days; on the eighth day you shall give it to Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall be holy people to Me, therefore you shall not eat any flesh torn to pieces in the field; you shall throw it to the dogs.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not give a false report; do not join your hand with a wicked person to be a malicious witness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not follow the crowd in doing evil, nor shall you testify in a dispute so as to join together with a crowd in order to pervert justice;
speaker: Narrator

text: nor shall you show favor to a poor person in his dispute.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you encounter your enemy’s ox or his donkey wandering away, you must return it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see the donkey of one who hates you lying helpless under its load, you shall not leave it helpless for its owner; you must arrange the load with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not pervert the justice due to your needy brother in his dispute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep far from a false charge, and do not kill the innocent or the righteous, for I will not acquit the guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not take a bribe, for a bribe blinds the clear-sighted and subverts the cause of the just.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not oppress a stranger, since you yourselves know the feelings of a stranger, for you also were strangers in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now you shall sow your land for six years and gather in its yield,
speaker: Narrator

text: but in the seventh year you shall let it rest and lie uncultivated, so that the needy of your people may eat; and whatever they leave the animal of the field may eat. You are to do the same with your vineyard and your olive grove.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For six days you are to do your work, but on the seventh day you shall cease from labor so that your ox and your donkey may rest, and the son of your female slave, as well as the stranger residing with you, may refresh themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now concerning everything which I have said to you, be careful; and do not mention the name of other gods, nor let them be heard from your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Three times a year you shall celebrate a feast to Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread; for seven days you are to eat unleavened bread, as I commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Abib, for in that month you came out of Egypt. And no one is to appear before Me empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator
